title: How to Restore Old Photos: AI-Powered Photo Restoration Guide
content:
## Introduction

Old photographs fade, scratch, and degrade over time, but AI technology can restore them to their former glory. Our free Image Restoration tool uses AI to repair damage, reduce noise, enhance clarity, and bring vintage photos back to life.

## Key Takeaways

- Restore faded, scratched, and damaged photos
- AI automatically repairs common damage types
- Enhance clarity and reduce noise
- Improve contrast and color balance
- Preserve original details while repairing

## What is Photo Restoration?

Photo restoration uses AI to analyze damaged images and intelligently repair:

- Scratches and creases
- Fading and discoloration
- Noise and grain
- Spots and stains
- Tears and missing portions

## Step-by-Step Guide

### Step 1: Scan or Upload

Upload your damaged photo. For physical photos:
- Scan at 300 DPI minimum
- Use flatbed scanner if possible
- Avoid glare and reflections
- Capture full image

### Step 2: AI Analysis

The tool analyzes your image for:
- Scratches and creases
- Color degradation
- Noise levels
- Missing details

### Step 3: Automatic Restoration

AI applies repairs:
- Scratch removal
- Color correction
- Noise reduction
- Clarity enhancement

### Step 4: Review and Download

Compare before/after. Download your restored image.

## Best Practices and Tips

### Scanning Old Photos

**For best results:**
- Scan at 300-600 DPI
- Use RAW or TIFF if possible
- Clean scanner glass
- Handle photos carefully

**Scanning tips:**
| Issue | Solution |
|-------|----------|
| Curled photos | Gently flatten |
| Stuck-together prints | Consult professional |
| Fragile originals | Use glass or sleeve |
| Reflective surfaces | Adjust lighting |

### Maximizing Restoration Quality

**Input quality matters:**
- Higher resolution = better results
- Clean scans work better
- Consistent lighting helps
- Original photos preferred over copies

**Setting expectations:**
| Damage Level | Expected Outcome |
|--------------|------------------|
| Light (fading, minor scratches) | Excellent |
| Moderate (yellowing, some spots) | Very good |
| Heavy (tears, major damage) | Variable |
| Severe (missing portions) | Limited |

### After Restoration

- Save in high-quality format
- Keep original scan as backup
- Consider multiple restoration passes
- Print on archival paper for longevity

## Understanding AI Restoration

### What AI Does Well

- Pattern recognition for scratch removal
- Color prediction for faded areas
- Noise pattern identification
- Consistent enhancement application

### AI Limitations

- Cannot recreate missing faces
- May smooth over fine details
- Cannot guarantee color accuracy
- Major damage needs human expertise

## Frequently Asked Questions

### How good is AI restoration compared to manual?

AI restoration handles common damage types well and works in seconds. Professional manual restoration can achieve superior results but takes hours and costs significantly more.

### Can AI restore severely damaged photos?

AI works best on light to moderate damage. Severely damaged photos with missing portions may need professional restoration combining AI and manual techniques.

### Will the restored photo look natural?

Modern AI aims for natural results, but some images may look slightly processed. Review results and consider multiple passes or manual touchups if needed.

### What resolution should I scan at?

300 DPI minimum for standard prints. 600 DPI for small photos or those needing significant enlargement. Higher is better but creates larger files.

### Can I restore photos of photos?

Direct scans work better than photos of photos. If you must photograph a print, use even lighting, perpendicular angle, and highest camera resolution.

### How do I preserve restored photos?

Save as high-quality PNG or TIFF for archives. Create multiple backups. For prints, use archival-quality paper and ink.
